Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Minority Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for FY 2010. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Samuel Diaz is "Cooperation and conflict in viruses during genetic exchange." The host institutions for this research are the University of California-San Diego and Yale University and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. Lin Chao and Dr. Paul Turner, respectively.

Genetic exchange occurs in some viruses and affects properties such as virulence and host specificity. This project uses social evolution theory to examine the roles of cooperation and conflict during genetic exchange, wherein referred to as "sex." In a process roughly similar to sexual reproduction, "sex" occurs in some viruses when genomic fragments mix during infection of a cell, creating progeny with fragments from different parental viruses. Laboratory studies have shown that depending on the density of infecting viruses, viruses can evolve strategies to exchange genetic material evenly (termed cooperation, as in sexual reproduction) or to bias genetic exchange in their favor (termed conflict, as in meiotic drive). This project uses natural isolates of the Cystoviridae as a model system to understand how viral reproductive strategies evolve in nature. These strategies play a role in the emergence of a variety of viruses and this study enhances understanding of genetic exchange in viruses.

The training goals include standard microbial isolation, plating, viral fitness assays, development of new genetic techniques, and theoretical and modeling skills. Broader impacts include mentoring McNair Scholars, a program proven to enhance undergraduate advancement. Outreach efforts beyond the campus walls involve high school students and teachers in the UCSD Early Academic Outreach Program and participation in the Science Matters public lecture series held at off-campus museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cooperation and conflict in viruses during genetic exchange
Viruses are commonly known as microscopic particles that cause disease in humans. However, the impact of viruses on human lives is much larger, because viruses affect all life on the planet (including animals, plants, fungi, bacteria, etc.). Viruses alter their hosts by infecting their cells and using cell resources to make copies of themselves. The survival of viruses depends on successful exploitation of their hosts, yet this is not enough: Viruses have to contend with other viruses also attempting to use the same cell resources. This is because in many environments there are more viruses than cells, and more than one virus can infect a given cell at the same time. These co-infections can lead to viral genetic exchange, or sex, because the genetic material of viruses can mix, generating offspring viruses that are a mix of the parent viruses. 

Genetic exchange can help viruses infect new hosts, secrete new toxins, spread their range, replicate more efficiently, and become more virulent. Despite the importance of genetic exchange to viral biology, the basics of the social lives of viruses –how viruses interact–, are not well understood. How frequently does genetic exchange occur in nature? How is viral reproduction affected by the infection of other viruses? Does genetic similarity predict frequency of sex? Can viruses change their social environment? I researched these questions using bacteria-killing viruses called bacteriophages; specifically the Cystoviruses that infect Pseudomonas bacteria that are common plant pathogens.

I found that cystoviruses isolated from natural environments are able to readily exchange genes with a related virus in the lab. I also show viruses isolated from different geographic locations differ in their ability to exchange genes. At least under the experimental conditions of the project, the geographic origin of viruses was more important than genetic similarity in predicting the rate of genetic exchange. Together with previous studies, my results suggest that genetic exchange contributes to the patterns viral distribution in the landscape.

I also found that cystoviruses are capable of changing cell conditions to alter the chance of additional viruses entering the cell. Any particular virus-bacterium pair has a specific rate at which viruses attach to the cells, the attachment rate. I examined a variety of cystoviruses and found that the attachment rates changed according a measure of the social environment (the number of viruses per bacterium or multiplicity of infection, MOI). Specifically, some strains showed an increased attachment rate at intermediate viral densities (MOI’s), suggesting that viruses can change cell conditions to “recruit” other viruses into the infection. These results suggest that viruses may have traits to mediate interactions with other viruses.

The cystoviruses are a powerful study system to understand interactions between viruses. My research suggests that genetic exchange differs according to location, suggesting we can identify areas of rapid virus evolution. My research also highlights the importance of viral social interactions by uncovering potential ways viruses negotiate the presence of other viruses.

The purpose of this Postodoctoral Fellowship was to obtain advanced scientific training to prepare me for a research career.
